questions.question: Question 1: What is the innermost layer of the sclera?
questions.explanation:
Lamina fusca is the innermost layer of the sclera. Lamina fusca faces the choroid. It is the transition zone between the sclera and the choroid. It 
consists of a delicate meshwork of elastic fibres, fibrocytes and melanocytes, traversed by long 
posterior ciliary nerves and vessels. Layers of the sclera from outside to inside include episclera, sclera proper, and lamina fusca, in 
that order.

questions.question: Question 2: The sclera is the thinnest at which of the following locations?

options.c: Anterior to attachment of the superior rectus
options.d: Posterior to attachment of the superior rectus

questions.explanation:
The sclera is the thinnest posterior to the insertion of the rectus muscles. The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, with maximum thickness around the optic nerve, 0.66 mm at 
the insertions of the rectus muscles and 0.33 mm beneath the rectus muscles and thinnest behind 
their insertions

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient sustained a severe blow to the right eye from the lateral side during a fistfight. The 
eyeball is soft to touch and a rupture of the sclera is suspected. What is the least likely site of 
rupture?
questions.explanation:
The lateral limbus is the least likely site to be involved in a traumatic scleral rupture. Traumatic scleral rupture, or globe rupture, occurs after blunt-force trauma. It usually occurs due 
to the compression force of the trauma. It therefore likely occurs at the insertion of rectus 
muscles, at the equator, or in an area parallel to the limbus opposite from the site of the impact. 
Rupture at the site of trauma, in this case lateral limbus, is rare. The major signs of scleral rupture are conjunctival edema and subconjunctival hemorrhage, 
hyphema, ocular hypotony, impairment or dislocation of the lens, vitreous hemorrhage, and 
retinal detachment.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the predominant type of collagen in the sclera?
questions.explanation:
Collagen type I is the predominant type of collagen found in the sclera. Collagen forms 50 to 75% of the dry weight of the sclera. Type II is absent in the sclera. It is found 
in the vitreous body of the eye. 124 
Sold by @itachibot

staphyloma. Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma. Staphyloma is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of 
the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak

Staphyloma (a bunch of grapes) is a clinical condition characterized by ectasia (dilation or 
bulging) of the outer coats (cornea or sclera or both) of the eye with the incarceration (trapping) of

questions.question: Question 7: The ciliary staphyloma is due to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ciliary staphyloma is due to scleritis. Ciliary staphyloma is the ectasia (bulging) of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the 
ciliary zone that includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. It can be caused by scleritis, 
absolute glaucoma or trauma to the ciliary region of the eye. The image below shows ciliary staphyloma with scleritis.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which 
of the following condition commonly causes this? 119 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Irritation in the eye associated with areas of scleral thinning through which the uvea shines is 
suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. 
Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity of the 
sclera is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue. Other collagen disorders associated with it are as follows: • Wegener’s granulomatosis (option B) • Polyarteritis nodosa (option A) • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) • Ankylosing spondylitis • Relapsing polychondritis 127 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: The most common type of scleritis is  
.
questions.explanation:
Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis is the most common type of scleritis. Scleritis can be classified into anterior and posterior scleritis. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in 
front of the equator, while posterior scleritis affects the sclera behind the equator of the eye. 
Anterior scleritis is further classified into the following types: • Non-necrotizing • Diffuse: The most common variety • Nodular: Scleral nodules are present. Annular scleritis is a variant in which the scleral nodules 
are arranged in a ring around the limbus. • Necrotizing • With inflammation • Without inflammation: Also known as scleromalacia perforans. It is seen in elderly females with 
long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. The image below shows anterior nodular scleritis.

questions.question: Question 10: All the following statements are true for a 40-year-old diagnosed with scleritis except-

options.a: Scleromalacia perforans is associated with systemic disease.
options.b: Pain is not a prominent feature.
options.d: Retinal detachment is a known complication.

questions.explanation:
Pain is a prominent feature of scleritis. Scleritis is an inflammation of the sclera. Patients present with moderate to severe eye pain, 
redness, lacrimation and photophobia. Anterior scleritis affects the sclera in front of the equator 
and may lead to the following complications: • Acute infiltrative stromal keratitis • Sclerosing keratitis • Peripheral ulcerative keratitis 128 
Sold by @itachibot • Uveitis • Glaucoma • Hypotony (rarely phthisis) • Perforation of the sclera Posterior scleritis involves the sclera behind the equator and may lead to uveal effusion with 
choroidal detachment, disc edema, proptosis or exudative retinal detachment. Scleromalacia perforans is a type of anterior scleritis. It typically occurs in elderly women with 
rheumatoid arthritis (systemic disease). There is ischemia and necrosis of the sclera; however, 
there is no inflammation. Clinically, it is a painless condition with a white eye. Areas of thinned 
out sclera through which the uvea shines are seen in such patients.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 63-year-old woman presented with a two-week history of gradually worsening sharp and 
stabbing left eye pain with redness. The severe pain kept her awakened during the night. On 
investigation, B-scan ultrasound shows the 'T' sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon 
space. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of severe worsening eye pain with redness and a B-scan showing T sign 
due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space is suggestive of posterior scleritis. Posterior scleritis is the inflammation involving the sclera behind the equator. Ultrasonography in 
posterior scleritis may show the following: • Increased scleral thickness • Scleral nodules • Separation of tenon capsule from the sclera • Disc oedema • Choroidal folds • Retinal detachment • Fluid in the sub-tenon space may give a characteristic "T" sign. The stem of the "T" is formed by 
the optic nerve and the cross-bar by the fluid-containing gap. The image given below shows a B-scan ocular ultrasound of the eye. 129 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient develops surgically induced necrotising scleritis following an ocular surgery. The 
patient most likely underwent any of the following surgeries except:
questions.explanation:
Surgically induced necrotizing scleritis (SINS) may occur following any ocular surgery involving 
the creation of a scleral wound. Tarso-frontalis sling surgery is a lid surgery and does not involve 
the sclera. SINS is a condition of scleral inflammation and necrosis that may occur as a complication of the 
following surgeries: • Pterygium excision • Cataract surgery (especially with sclero-corneal tunnel) • Trabeculectomy • Vitreo-retinal surgeries • Squint surgery SINS is more likely to develop in those with rheumatoid arthritis, connective tissue disorders or 
following intra-operative use of mitomycin C. It is treated with NSAIDS and systemic steroids.

questions.question:
Question 13: As a first-year ophthalmology resident, you come across a child with the following 
presentation. Which of the following disorders is it associated with? 121 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The child has blue sclera which is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta. Blue scleral discoloration is due to scleral thinning. The underlying uvea thus becomes prominent 
and visible. Osteogenesis imperfecta (types I and IIA) and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type VI) are 
the most commonly associated diseases. Both diseases are inherited disorders of collagen 
formation. Other options: 130 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Hemochromatosis occurs due to iron deposition in various tissues. Rusty-brown 
perilimbal conjunctiva and scleral discoloration are seen. Option C: Congenital ocular melanocytosis occurs due to an increase in the number, size and 
pigmentation of melanocytes. Sclera is multifocal slate-grey pigmented. Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis may present with extraarticular manifestations such as secondary 
Sjo■gren’s syndrome where keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be seen.

questions.question: Question 14: The sclera is thick in all the following conditions except-
questions.explanation:
The sclera is not thick in buphthalmos. The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, 0.66mm thick at the insertion of recti and 0.33mm thick 
beneath the recti. In buphthalmos, the sclera is stretched and thinned out, resulting in “blue 
sclera.” Buphthalmos refers to an enlarged eyeball due to congenital glaucoma.

questions.question:
Question 15: An intern comes across a 7-year-old girl with the following features. All the following are 
components of her condition except- 122 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of a young girl with facial asymmetry, deviation of angle of the mouth, flat 
nasal bridge, preauricular tags and limbal dermoid (lenticular yellow tumour at the limbus) of the 
eye is suggestive of Goldenhar syndrome. Lung hypoplasia is not a component of this syndrome. Goldenhar syndrome or oculoauriculovertebral spectrum is a congenital developmental anamoly 
affecting structures derived from the first branchial arch. It has the following features: • Systemic: • Hypoplasia of the malar, maxillary, and mandibular regions • Macrostomia and microtia • Preauricular and facial skin tags • Hemivertebrae (usually cervical) • Mental handicap • Cardiac, renal, and central nervous system (CNS) anomalies. • Ocular: • Dermoid • Upper lid notching or coloboma • Microphthalmos • Disc coloboma 131 
Sold by @itachibot Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis
